Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 03:44PM Yogi70 wrote: Yue, Herceptin can be used alone.  Right now I'm doing herceptin/taxol.  I have 6 more taxol treatments but after that I'll just be on herceptin.  But from what I've read and heard there are benefits of combining herceptin with chemo (with consideration of heart problems).  You would want to look into that to get the maximum benefit.  God Bless.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 08:14AM Yogi70 wrote: Well first of all ladies, you have to eat.  Sometimes that metallic taste in your mouth puts you off eating. I'm sure more ladies will be chiming in to help you but I think chewing on ice helps prevent the sores in the mouth. Some suggestions may be to eat things that are kind of bland.  You might want to try crackers and soup, broths, jello, applesauce, etc.  Things that you can tolerate.  I really didn't have too much of a problem with my appetite but those are some of the suggestions I've seen and read about.  I am sure someone else will chime with more help.  I hope you both feel better. Yogi

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2008 10:34PM - edited Jul 6, 2008 10:35PM by Yogi70 No, it's not just vanity. It may seem like vanity because of the way society views hair.  But your hair is a part of you and although we know it grows back, its traumatic to watch it and feel it fall off your scalp in clumps.  It's like I told my mother, losing my hair made me feel more like I had cancer than losing my breast did (go figure). I really can't compare it to losing a limb, but it feels like it may be somewhere in that neighborhood given the trauma of the diagnosis and everything that goes along with having breast cancer.  I don't think your friend can relate to how you feel and I hope she never does but it's certainly not a vanity thing.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 04:32PM Yogi70 wrote: My hair looks like it'll be growing back in patches at least I can see a little of it.  I have 2 more taxol tx left and then it rads and the remainder of herceptin (so I'm wondering about the growth factor).  I am getting hair on my legs and arms again.  I'm not even checking for lashes and brows (i just pencil in my brows).  Hair "down there" is trying to come back but I have always kept that hairless so I'm back to that.  I'm getting a little underarm hair, hate that, I'll have to shave soon. So there's my hair update. How is everybody?

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 11:32AM Yogi70 wrote: The hot flashes will eventually lessen and go away. I am 38 and at first the hot flashes were horrendous. I used to take ice packs and place them any where on my body to get a little relief. I would also keep one under my pillow to put my hands or my head on during the night. I finished chemo August 27 and they have gotten milder and milder. I count 3 or 4 a day now but they are no where near as bad as before, so hold on. Relief is on the way.
Posts.Title: Hot flashes! towens88 Curlylocks

Posts.Content: Yogi70 wrote: Has anyone had a problem with taxol and low wbc?  I keep having this problem, I was fine with Adriamycin but I keep having to get neuprogin shots for taxol.  I was supposed to get treatment Wednesday, my count was low so they gave me a neuprogin shot and rescheduled tx for today.  Well, my count was also low today and I was given a shot.  I also have to get another shot tomorrow at the emergency room (doctor referral) and go back Monday and hopefully my counts will be up so I can get treatment.   I don't have a fever and I feel fine and am taking care.  Has anyone else had this experience? Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 02:06AM Yogi70 wrote: Andraw, Please let your sister know the truth so that she can have a say in her treatment. She will probably surprise you with her strength.  Her situation is NOT hopeless.  There are many women on these boards who are living great lives and doing fine even in the late stages of this disease.  I for one am a Stage III with 13/15 positive nodes and I don't feel hopeless.  As long as we're here there's always hope.  Please pass this along to your sister we would love to hear from her. You are a very loving and caring sister and she is blessed to have you.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 07:58AM Yogi70 wrote: Joanne, Hi, it's okay to have the feelings you're having, but you've come to the right place!!!  We're sisters here and we all help each other.  I'm sorry you have to be here at all ((((HUG)))).  What chemo are you starting?  I started with dd (dense dose) A/C and now I am on Taxol/herceptin.  My first A/C I did pretty well.  But after the second - fourth treatments I would have to stay in bed anywhere from 2 to 3 days but after that I was just fine.  I did my first treatment of A/C on March 11 and lost my hair on March 30 so it'll take about 2 wks give or take a few days.  But since I'm on taxol I actually see a little peach fuzz so I'm encouraged by that.  Hang in there Joanne.  There will be more of us chiming in.  You're not alone.
Posts.Title: Tact 2 Chemo - Starting it in a couple of weeks joanne32 Jule

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 08:40PM Yogi70 wrote: I found a lump under my arm and when I had the biopsy my doctor said that it was probably nothing to worry about.  He was sure it was benign.  Well, it was cancer.  It took two stereotactic biopsies and at last one surgical biopsy to actually findd the tumor which he estimated to be about 1.8cm.  It is also surrounded by smaller tumors.  So one radical modified mastectomy coming up (right).  Right now its surreal.  I intend to keep a positive attitude but I know that's easier said that done.
